natural problem: I have four identical oranges. How many ways are there for me to divide these oranges into at most three groups?  (By definition, a group must have at least one orange.)
natural solution: All the oranges can go in one group, or $3$ can go in one group and $1$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and $2$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and each of the other $2$ can be in a group by itself.
As a list, we have: \begin{align} &4 \\ &3,1\\ &2,2\\ &2,1,1. \end{align} This gives a total of $\boxed{4}$ possibilities.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes oranges groups ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "groups > 0"
shows  "ways = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have four identical oranges. How many ways are there for me to divide these oranges into at most three groups?  (By definition, a group must have at least one orange.) The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 All the oranges can go in one group, or $3$ can go in one group and $1$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and $2$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and each of the other $2$ can be in a group by itself.
 As a list, we have: \begin{align} &4 \\ &3,1\\ &2,2\\ &2,1,1. \end{align} This gives a total of $\boxed{4}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes oranges groups ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "groups > 0"
shows  "ways = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In how many ways can 4 oranges be distributed into no more than 3 non-empty groups? The final answer is 4 ways.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes oranges :: nat and groups :: "'a set set"
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "card (UNION groups id) = oranges"
and h2 : "finite groups"
and h3 : "\<forall>g \<in> groups. card g \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "card groups \<le> 3"
shows  "card {groups. card (UNION groups id) = oranges \<and> finite groups \<and> (\<forall>g \<in> groups. card g \<ge> 1) \<and> card groups \<le> 3} = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have four identical oranges. How many ways are there for me to divide these oranges into at most three groups?  (By definition, a group must have at least one orange.) The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 All the oranges can go in one group, or $3$ can go in one group and $1$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and $2$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and each of the other $2$ can be in a group by itself.
 As a list, we have: \begin{align} &4 \\ &3,1\\ &2,2\\ &2,1,1. \end{align} This gives a total of $\boxed{4}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes oranges :: nat and groups :: "'a set set"
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "card (UNION groups id) = oranges"
and h2 : "finite groups"
and h3 : "\<forall>g \<in> groups. card g \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "card groups \<le> 3"
shows  "card {groups. card (UNION groups id) = oranges \<and> finite groups \<and> (\<forall>g \<in> groups. card g \<ge> 1) \<and> card groups \<le> 3} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: You have 4 oranges and want to divide them into groups. Each group must have at least 1 orange. You can have at most 3 groups. How many different ways can you arrange the oranges into these groups? The final answer is 4.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes oranges groups :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "groups > 0"
shows  "card {ways :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) | ways. (\<forall>i. (i \<le> groups) \<longrightarrow> (ways i > 0)) \<and> (\<forall>i. i > groups \<longrightarrow> ways i = 0) \<and> (\<Sum>i\<le>groups. ways i) = oranges } = 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have four identical oranges. How many ways are there for me to divide these oranges into at most three groups?  (By definition, a group must have at least one orange.) The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 All the oranges can go in one group, or $3$ can go in one group and $1$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and $2$ in another group, or $2$ can go in one group and each of the other $2$ can be in a group by itself.
 As a list, we have: \begin{align} &4 \\ &3,1\\ &2,2\\ &2,1,1. \end{align} This gives a total of $\boxed{4}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes oranges groups :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "groups > 0"
shows  "card {ways :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) | ways. (\<forall>i. (i \<le> groups) \<longrightarrow> (ways i > 0)) \<and> (\<forall>i. i > groups \<longrightarrow> ways i = 0) \<and> (\<Sum>i\<le>groups. ways i) = oranges } = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 4 oranges that need to be distributed into no more than 3 groups. Each group must have at least 1 orange. How many different ways can the oranges be distributed? The final answer is 4.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat and oranges :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "ways = card {groups. (\<exists>A B C. groups = {A, B, C} \<and> (\<forall>G\<in>groups. G \<noteq> {}) \<and> (\<forall>o\<in>oranges. \<exists>!G\<in>groups. o \<in> G))}"
shows  "ways = 4"

 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes oranges groups :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> g. g \<in> {1..groups} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n oranges_in_group g)"
shows  "card {ways :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) set. \<forall> f \<in> ways. sum f {1..groups} = oranges} = 4"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have four identical oranges. How many ways are there for me to divide these oranges into at most three groups?  (By definition, a group must have at least one orange.) The final Answer is 4

 As a list, we have: \begin{align} &4 \\ &3,1\\ &2,2\\ &2,1,1. \end{align} This gives a total of $\boxed{4}$ possibilities.
 *)

theorem
fixes oranges groups :: nat
assumes h0 : "oranges = 4"
and h1 : "groups \<le> 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> g. g \<in> {1..groups} \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n oranges_in_group g)"
shows  "card {ways :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) set. \<forall> f \<in> ways. sum f {1..groups} = oranges} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: You have 4 oranges and want to divide them into no more than 3 groups. How many ways can you distribute the oranges into the groups, with at least 1 orange in each group? The final answer is 4.
